articles.title: Sensational Canada shock New Zealand to make final
articles.summary: Canada inflict New Zealand's first defeat in 11 years at the Womens' Rugby World Cup as a sensational performance books their place in the Twickenham final.
articles.content:
Even their most ardent fans though would not have expected victory by such an emphatic margin.

After first-half tries from scrum-half Justine Pelletier, wing Asia Hogan-Rochester, centre Florence Symonds and second row Sophie de Goede, Canada headed down the tunnel 17 points clear.

Three minutes after the restart, centre Alex Tessier, who plays her club rugby in Exeter, stepped off her right foot and sauntered in to make it 31-7 and all but extinguish Kiwi hopes.

New Zealand defended their world title by overhauling England's double-digit lead in the final at Eden Park three years ago.

However, they did not have to make up such a vast deficit and, despite Liana Mikaele-Tu'u crossing from close range and Braxton Sorensen-McGee being put in by Ruahei Demant's cross-field punt, they never looked like producing another famous comeback as 24,392 fans at Ashton Gate acclaimed the deserved victors.

Canada head coach Kevin Rouet was clearly delighted but eager to focus his players' minds on the final at Twickenham next week and not get too carried away with their celebrations.

"I said to the girls to stop crying because we have a job to do in eight days," he said. "That's the mindset. We need to finish the job and be ready in eight days.

"I felt it already one and a half years ago that we could do something and I am happy we are one game away from achieving what we want. I am excited for next weekend. I want it to be next weekend now."

Black Ferns captain Kennedy Tukuafu said: "Canada were exceptional and it will be a great final.

"I think how far the women's game has come, it's pretty special to be part of this legacy, to see how big this tournament's been, the biggest there's ever been, so we can be proud of contributing to that."

articles.personality_title: Notre-Dame’s bell towers reopen to the public after restoration
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – In 2019, a fire badly damaged Notre-Dame Cathedral in Paris, especially its roof and part of its structure. Since then, the cathedral has been closed to visitors while repairs were made.

**What happened** – The bell towers of Notre-Dame, the last part of the cathedral to be restored, have now reopened to the public. French President Emmanuel Macron officially opened them just before the European Heritage Days event, a time when many historic sites in Europe welcome visitors.

**Impact** – This reopening lets people see Paris from one of its most famous landmarks, offering unique views from the towers. It also marks an important step in bringing back a beloved cultural and historical site that many people missed since the fire.

**What's next step** – During the European Heritage Days, the entire cathedral will be open again to visitors. Other historic places and special events, like a chocolate workshop by a top French chef, will also be available to enjoy.

**One-sentence takeaway** – After years of repairs, Notre-Dame’s bell towers are open again, giving visitors a chance to experience a famous part of Paris and its history.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les clochers de Notre-Dame rouvrent au public après restauration
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – En 2019, un incendie a gravement endommagé la cathédrale Notre-Dame à Paris, notamment son toit et une partie de sa structure. Depuis, la cathédrale était fermée au public pendant les travaux de réparation.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Les clochers de Notre-Dame, dernière partie à être restaurée, ont maintenant rouvert au public. Le président français Emmanuel Macron les a officiellement inaugurés juste avant les Journées européennes du patrimoine, un événement où de nombreux sites historiques en Europe ouvrent leurs portes.

**Impact** – Cette réouverture permet aux visiteurs de voir Paris depuis l’un de ses monuments les plus célèbres, offrant une vue unique depuis les clochers. C’est aussi une étape importante pour redonner vie à un site culturel et historique très apprécié, que beaucoup attendaient depuis l’incendie.

**Prochaine étape** – Pendant les Journées européennes du patrimoine, toute la cathédrale sera de nouveau accessible aux visiteurs. D’autres lieux historiques et événements spéciaux, comme un atelier de chocolat dirigé par un grand chef français, seront aussi proposés.

**Phrase clé** – Après plusieurs années de travaux, les clochers de Notre-Dame sont ouverts à nouveau, permettant aux visiteurs de découvrir une partie célèbre de Paris et son histoire.
articles.personality_title_es: Las torres de Notre-Dame reabren al público tras la restauración
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – En 2019, un incendio causó graves daños en la catedral de Notre-Dame en París, especialmente en su techo y parte de su estructura. Desde entonces, la catedral estuvo cerrada mientras se realizaban las reparaciones.

**Qué pasó** – Las torres de campanas de Notre-Dame, la última parte en ser restaurada, han vuelto a abrir al público. El presidente francés Emmanuel Macron las inauguró oficialmente justo antes de los Días Europeos del Patrimonio, cuando muchos sitios históricos en Europa abren sus puertas.

**Impacto** – Esta reapertura permite a las personas ver París desde uno de sus monumentos más famosos, ofreciendo vistas únicas desde las torres. También representa un paso importante para recuperar un sitio cultural e histórico muy querido que muchos extrañaban desde el incendio.

**Próximo paso** – Durante los Días Europeos del Patrimonio, toda la catedral estará abierta de nuevo a los visitantes. Otros lugares históricos y eventos especiales, como un taller de chocolate dirigido por un reconocido chef francés, también estarán disponibles.

**Conclusión en una frase** – Tras años de reparaciones, las torres de Notre-Dame están abiertas nuevamente, dando a los visitantes la oportunidad de vivir una parte famosa de París y su historia.
